title: Will Russia conduct a flight test of an RS-28 Sarmat ICBM before 1 August 2021?
preds: Comments: Incremental adjustment for the passage of time.

I expect to do well on this question, although not as well as cafe.  I had no specific knowledge of this question, nor really the desire to research.  But i recognized that the crowd bias was along the lines of alarmist western media.  Heavily that they would. Yet, technology development is hard, and usually fails to meet  project goals. My strategy on this question was to wait.  If the crowd was right, no harm.  If I got motivated to research I could come in earlier. Otherwise just score free points by capitalizing on crowd misread

The test may still happen (or even already has happened, successful or unsuccessful), but it is just a few days left - time to make a few points: how it could happen that the crowd forecast went from almost 100% (I believe 87% was the top) probability to 1%.
Let's start with the caveat - it is just my personal opinion and I do not pretend I have a crystal ball. Several factors contributed to overestimation. I think the main one is that in mass media (both, in Russia and the West) Putin is portrayed is almost almighty macho leader who orders something and it happens. He can order the launch right on the Victory Day. Or right before meeting with Biden to show who's the boss. The reality is more nuanced. Russia has limited resources and the military, after modernization in recent years, is not the main priority - domestic stability is. Putin does not want to start arms race that Russia cannot win - more powerful Soviet Union ended up in a history dustbin because of that.  Sarmat, which will supposedly change the balance of power, cannot be pushed to the fore by all means necessary. Besides,  its capabilities, especially hypersonic ones, may have been overhyped.  Other factors contributed too. It was a Ukrainian rocket design bureau, with relevant expertise, that was given the project at the beginning. After 2014 (with Crimea annexed by Russia and military conflict in Donbass) it could not continue and the project was transferred to a Russian rocket design bureau that did not have experience in designing such big rockets. Hence all delays and difficulties. At the beginning of this year, it was reported that Russians started building a new testing range from scratch in taiga near Krasnoyarsk, devoted specifically to testing of Sarmat. This testing range was supposed to be finished at the end of 2021 and unusually difficulties of a construction of the range were reported - most probably, to justify delays of the launch. Not sure it was discussed here at GJOP. Yes, I was swayed myself by pronouncements that Sarmat was going to be launched "very, very soon" by powerful people. And I believe it may happen - later this quarter or somewhere at the end of the year or beginning of the next. Or not - technical difficulties may have been too high.   Regardless, it was an interesting exercise.
Down 10% for passage of time. I think I was asleep at the switch for awhile.
Nothing reported in connection with the Navy Day. Still clear as mud, of course, but decreasing further, in part to compensate for the earlier high level of confidence in a “yes” outcome.
Comments: Incremental adjustment down due to passage of time.
Comments: Incremental adjustment down due to passage of time.

Of the three “unique armaments” promised by Putin “in the near future” (https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/putin-just-made-big-promise-russian-military-even-better-weapons-188888), only Sarmat remains to be tested. Zircon and S-500 tests are in the news. On the other hand, only a short time left in this question.

Another missile test, this time I believe Zircon(?)  as it was reportedly hypersonic.  Two in two months is certainly telling of Russia's desire to show off their arsenal; however, with so little time to go I actually thinks this lowers my probability rather than raises it.

Down 30% for passage of time. The hypersonic aspect (delayed or not wanted to be displayed) makes sense; the SS-18 update not so certain. RU has plenty of nukes with multiple delivery platforms. They don't need to send any "message" although sometimes it appears they do.
Chest beating continues which probably takes more time to play out.

Comments: Aggressive messaging continues. Incremental adjustment down due to time constraint.
Insider, 07/15/21, 'With close military encounters on opposite sides of the world, Russia is sending a message to the West': https://www.businessinsider.com/close-military-encounters-are-message-from-russia-to-the-west-2021-7
The Sun, 07/15/21, 'PUTIN ON THE BLITZ Russia boasts of ‘most modernised military arsenal in the world’ after intercepting US warplanes as NATO tensions mount': https://www.the-sun.com/news/3288595/russia-boasts-most-modernised-military-arsenal-world/

https://t.me/warbolts/528
https://t.me/warbolts/530 Not sure what to make of this in the context of this question: The Google Earth-like “before” and “after” photos seem to show that the missile launch facility for ICBM Sarmat is being modernized. Whether this is in prep for the promised flight test or independent of it is unclear, but I’m going to assume Russia is not ready yet and the MLFs will have to be built out/modernized first.
Down with time and the crowd.
Comments: See @yagudin link about recent ICBM test launch. Design bureau/manufacturer different from Sarmat. Reducing probability by 50% due to time constraints.

Russia tries its best to normalize relation with the West right now, because in case it is not successfull in that effort, and relations deteriorate, it will become 100% dependent on China in every regard except food, oil/gas and raw resrouces. Test ICBM in that situation? Not likely at all.
Decreasing due to passing of time.
Time is passing by with a  month left.

- https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11736413 — head of the rocket factory restates plans to test Sarmat in Q3  
- http://kremlin.ru/events/president/news/65942 — Putin mentions that Sarmat is coming soon
- https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/4878133 — another ICBM was successfully tested in mid-June

Relevant primarily because of the timing/reporting issues: 
FTA: Russia successfully test launches new intercontinental ballistic missile -TASS cites source 
“The launch took place in mid-June, the source said.”
https://www.euronews.com/2021/06/28/us-russia-missile
<—Reported by TASS on June 28. The source doesn’t specify which IBM, although a launch test and flight test may be different for our purposes anyway(?). Plesetsk is also the expected site for Sarmat’s launch (and for several other missiles). 
So: 
(A) there’s obviously activity on site. Does this make the promised flight test more likely? Boots on the ground, prep underway?
(B) Will it be reported as it happens, or only after the fact, and only if successful? 
(C) Is between now and end of this question enough time? 
Points B and C make me move a little closer to the crowd forecast.

- 20% → 12% per @Zauchka suggesting that MoD might not report an unsuccessful test.
- 12% → 15% per @probahilliby highlighting a successful launch of "_long-delayed_ next-generation ocean reconnaissance system."

I. There appears to be yet another space launch from the site in question, but at the end of the article it states that sanctions have been affecting the launch schedules. With new sanctions on Russia due to Navalny, this may directly or indirectly affect the ICBM tests. https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/06/soyuz-launches-pion-nks/ II. I am hesitant to remain at 33% for two main reasons: (1) The time window is relatively narrow and the closing date is nearing. (2) I may not be Fermi-izing all the factors properly. Perhaps a more proper forecast would be to multiply the probability of the time window of the 3rd quarter by the probability of the launch itself based on all available evidence. Assuming a naive probability of the latter, my forecast perhaps should be 33% x 50% = 16.5%. nts: 33 LL Y

Mentions of Sarmat in the media (in Russian), but actually nothing new. Just restating Q3 as a target period: https://ngs24.ru/text/gorod/2021/06/24/69988022/
https://военное.рф/2021/Дайджест22/
https://dela.ru/news/267973/ That still leaves us a month of July.

Moving up slightly with more declarations of a test in "Q3 this year" (where this question sits on a knife edge) and remembering that Met will rapidly degrade in the later parts of Q3 (making trials more weather dependant and "at risk), Putin's popularity slipping slightly (https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russias-putin-tries-give-ruling-party-pre-election-boost-with-spending-promises-2021-06-19/) and a number of interesting political events coming up in the next month or two that would make a successful test flight a popularity bung for the diminutive tsar to want to chase for the "national pride" vote. https://tass.com/defense/1306565

Russian media are reporting an unusual cloud over several areas up North that could be a trail left by an ICBM. https://life.ru/p/1405410
https://astrakhan-24.ru/news/misc/v_nebe_nad_astrakhanju_byl_zamechen_sled_ballisticheskoj_rakety_75790
While Sarmat is mentioned among the speculations, Topol-M is also (and possibly more) likely. 
There’s no reason to think the first flight test will be reported in the media immediately, especially if unsuccessful—or anytime prior to the launch. It could be reported at the most opportune time. (Putin’s annual televised call-in program? That’s June 30. Duma elections? That’s 19 September. Successful conclusion of all three flight tests? That’s ??? Maybe never?)

Possible between July and October, preferably near the election because that's when Russia historically does them. Now that brings up the possibility of being humiliated if a failure were to occur. But then again, they conducted many other tests before the one to come, so perhaps they have the confidence that it will be a success and they are just playing with it at this point. As for the argument regarding Russia's friendly reputation following the summit, here are my thoughts: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1296950 I'm starting to think their first test may very well be the full-range test. If they expect to launch 3 in 2021, with the first being in the third quarter (around election time), then that means on average 1.5–2.0 months between each test. By stating that the first and perhaps most difficult will be in the third quarter (period of 3 months), that sure is a heck of a lot of time, unless they also plan to do another or all tests in the third quarter as well. But to me, that signals that whatever they want to test in the third quarter in that first one, it may require time to process so the other tests can go forth in the remaining time of 2021. Russia is reportedly also working on a nuclear test—which is weird because if North Korea is also planning one, how strange for two nukes to be detonated within the same relative time. I would bet on the Russian one more likely to occur. But I digress. HOWEVER, August 1 is the closing date. That is still a far ways from election time, which would disprove my previous theory. And it is awfully close to now.
Updating slightly downwards, as time passes.
passage of time and positive summit
Better to try and fail than not to try.

A test so soon after the bilateral meeting would not send a friendly message.  Putin's meeting with Biden went better than expected with Putin publicly praising Biden's level of energy and sharpeness -- for what it may be worth. Seemed like a peace offering of some sort, Putin laying low, for now. Whats expected to come out of the meeting and the follow up yet to be seen but at least Putin doesn't seem to be taking an aggressive, provocative stand, for now. 
3 tests are expected this year and doesn't seem like preparations have stalled but less likely to happen in next 5 weeks...
Closer and closer. Reports are that there are exercises on the road-mobile ICBMs, but no evidence yet that the RS-28 will be tested by August.
Lowering due to passage of time and US-Russia meeting this past week

The optimal time for showmanship is (nearly?) over, so lowering again. Only one mention of RS-28 that I could find in the news: a popular tabloid MK says Biden was forced to call the summit in the face of new and formidable Russian arsenal, such as Sarmat. Biden would never admit this, however (according to MK), because it would cause psychological stress in the US to go through the roof. Which makes me think Sarmat, with all the publicity the Russian media work up around it, is great as a bogeyman. It will not serve this role very well if it starts failing tests. In other words, Russia would not test Sarmat unless they’re sure it will pass with flying colours—or unless they are sure they can present it that way.
Lower once July 1 arrives. There is Russian activity even near American territories despite the Biden-Putin summit. That tells me the military side may be separate from the political side.

Raising a bit more on the potential of showmanship around the Biden-Putin summit. Will swing back if nothing happens by the end of the week.  I found the original source of the 10-11 June test claim. It was a speculation on a military chat Telegram channel (“Voenno-boltovoy”) based on information that large ground areas around the launch site and the air space were off limits for those dates. No idea if: (a) the test took place and was not reported (yet?), (b) it was a drill before the actual test, (c) it was something else, or (d) the information is false. In any case, if true, there’s activity in the area, and Russian media continue to dutifully report every mention of Sarmat/RS-28/MBR 15A28 in foreign media. It seems to be perceived as great for PR.

The Russian news agency, Tass, writes "the first launch of the Sarmat ICBM within the framework of flight development tests will be carried out tentatively in the third quarter of 2021."  Before August 1, 2021 would be the first third of that quarter which already puts the probability at 33% if we assume there is a 100% chance they test it in the third quarter and that the probability of testing it at any time is uniform. Given the 5 non-conducted flight tests in 2020 I'd say the probability of this going through is at most 60% (0% historically but relations are rocky ATM).  I'm tentatively ignoring the meeting with Biden as I'm unsure if it will impact this question, will reevaluate after.   This leaves us with an upper bound of .6*33% = 20%, I'll lean towards this bound and start with an estimate of 17% yes.

Information field is murky, as is always the case related to the Russian military. This article says a full flight test will take place “no later than” 11 June: https://topcor.ru/20280-istochnik-polnocennyj-pusk-sarmata-provedut-v-blizhajshie-dni.html
Of course, 11 June has come and gone with no official announcement of the test. Did it happen and is awaiting a more opportune time to get an announcement? Did it happen and fail? Did it succumb to yet another delay?
Another source mentions a worker strike at a factory producing “Sarmat”: https://tayga.info/168482
However, workers are expected to be paid once “Sarmat” is delivered. Raising temporary. Note to self to check the news feed more frequently.

After the chatfest with Biden, Vlad the Shirtless will feel the need to flex something or other in public.  The pressure will be on his folks for a successful test, but this Q doesn't require success.  Coming up slightly. on the off-chance that this is the display he'll select for the occasion.

https://www.defensenews.com/air/2021/06/07/putin-confirms-russian-exit-from-open-skies-treaty/ Even though not directly related to ICBM tests and taking effect in six months, it signals that the Russian Federation is on a confrontational path and follows a renegade pattern of signalling, not caring too much about the impression it leaves with the international community. https://www.armyrecognition.com/weapons_defence_industry_military_technology_uk/russian_rs-28_sarmat_icbm_can_carry_several_types_of_warheads.html https://www.autoevolution.com/news/russias-fierce-sarmat-missile-closer-to-deployment-with-three-tests-this-year-160966.html
" 'Three launches of the Sarmat ICBM will be carried out as part of flight development tests in 2021,' one of them said.
'The first launch of the Sarmat ICBM within the framework of flight development tests will be carried out tentatively in the third quarter of 2021, a field at the Kura testing range on Kamchatka will be a target,' another source said."

Combat duty expected 2022
https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/russias-new-rs-28-sarmat-icbm-will-enter-combat-duty-next-year-184818
Miss clicked over correction.  Bloody slider...

Back down because the close proximity to the Biden meeting does not make sense. Additionally, it was once said that 5 tests were scheduled for 2020. That means one test every 2 to 3 months, which is eerily close to an annual quarter. So now it starts to make sense why they are saying the first test will occur during the first quarter. It may require them 2 to 3 months, on average, to produce a single test. Now the question is, will they prefer the test to be in the first, middle, or last part of the third quarter if at all.

A space launch from Plesetsk Cosmodrome has taken place recently, signaling that there is activity there. I found out that there are two launch silos active on the base, and that all three ICBM tests will come from one or both of these origins. We do know that the first is 'tentatively' scheduled to be in the third quarter, and one of the other two will test the full range of the ICBM. We must factor in the time it will take to reload the silo(s) with another ICBM(s). We still need to know whether these test launches are to be fired in relative proximity to each other, and what happened to the other two tests that are no longer planned.
Starting to look like not going to happen.

Comments: Good points @lsgold7, especially in light of recent move by Putin.

Now they are saying it WILL definitely start THIS year. Hmmm...

Just before or after Geneva Summit.
Testing new weapons has no downside.

Dropping further a bit. Only one new item in the Russian news in the past week that’s worth mentioning. According to Interfax.ru, deputy PM Yuri Borisov assured the journalists that “everything’s going according to the plan” and the flight tests will “definitely” start this year. Vague verbiage and assurances like this make me skeptical, especially as summer in the North is short (which may or may not be a material obstacle) and our deadline of 1 August is drawing near. OTOH, I should probably try to find out if they’ve actually ever given specific dates ahead of such tests in the past or simply announced after the fact. https://www.interfax.ru/russia/770594

Back up to be around the base rate of one third of the third quarter being in the forecast period. I also found the following information where it says testing is scheduled to be in the northwestern part of Russia. My first thought is COLD COLD COLD! So doing it in the summer when it's warmer is always a good idea. Average humidity via Weather Spark will be relatively high around the time which may influence the frequency of aborts. And the wind is relatively below normal around this time through August - kind of optimal but then again, the wind is probably negligible unless we're talking winter storms and higher-level winds that can cause wind shear on the rocket. Note, I did not include the climate for the rocket launch site(s) but rather the target area. https://www.autoevolution.com/news/russias-fierce-sarmat-missile-closer-to-deployment-with-three-tests-this-year-160966.html On the other hand, the following article says, "It will begin operations in 2022—and that is likely at the earliest."
https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/rs-28-sarmat-new-russian-icbm-enter-combat-duty-2022-174616 This article says, “'Research work on Kedr has been financed under the current state arms procurement program, which is in effect until 2027. Technological development will begin in 2023–2024,' a defense industry insider source told TASS."
https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/what-known-about-russia%E2%80%99s-secret-advanced-%E2%80%9Ckedr%E2%80%9D-nuclear-missile-184674 This article says Russia was supposed to receive two in 2021. So knowing if this actually occurred will help. https://thediplomat.com/2020/03/russia-upgrades-facility-to-produce-rs-28-sarmat-icbm/ This article says three are to be tested this third quarter. The fact that they have the audacity to report three tests and it has been the consistent narrative for years despite delays, we can assume the unlikely may actually happen. https://tass.com/defense/1286447 This page says two of the launches will be testing the ICBM's full range, which two me would most likely be the last two tests of the three, decreasing the probability of the first part of the third quarter. https://offstream.news/feed/2021/05/10/sources-in-russia-s-defense-industry-report-that-russia-will-be-carrying-out-three-tests-of-the-rs-28-sarmat-hypersonic.html But the again, the sooner they start, the more warm weather to work with. On the flipside, it's hard to see Russian soldiers in warmer weather while wearing thick/fluffy uniforms.
Comments: Entering 1st week of the 3rd quarter. Adjusting down 30% due to time constraint.
Dropping to 5%, especially with the Biden-Putin summit.

Biden and Putin are supposed to meet on June 16. Putin has an incentive to either conduct the test before the meeting or soon thereafter. However, the announcement made months ago stated the test was to be conducted in the 3rd quarter. That makes July the relevant month for this question although the test could easily fall into August or September and be consistent with their announcement. There is also the possibility that it happens before the 3rd quarter in the time right after their meeting (last 2 weeks in June). That totals a period of 6 weeks. I'm betting that Putin conducts the test soon after the summit and before August 1st.

I am starting to incorporate the Putin-Biden summit into my thinking (gives less odds of this question resolving YES). I find it unlikely . . . <10% . . . that Russia would do such a test around this time due to the summit. So, let's assume now till summit is unviable. Let's add a full week after the summit until things start to get viable again. That leaves us with only 18% of the time left to the year's end and 30% of the time left until the end of the 3rd quarter as stated by some articles here. Let's assume 75% chance by end of Q3. By end of August, that means 53% chance.  36% of the question timeframe is remaining. Let's multiply this by the probability/progress of 75%. That makes 27%. So now we have 18%, 27%, 30%, and 53%. Geo average 30, median is 29, simple average is 32. Let's take the median since that's usually more accurate and average it with the GJO average of 26% resolves YES: 28%. Drop to 20% if this goes unchallenged.
https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11307631 Russian sources report the first of the three flight tests planned for 2021 is expected in Q3.
Dropping with the passage of time.

Nothing new on Sarmat even after the Victory Day celebrations. The focus currently seems to be on the failed Kalibr test (https://defence-blog.com/news/russian-navy-weapon-test-ended-in-failure-after-cruise-missile-failed.html, https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9526021/Russian-frigate-narrowly-avoids-blasting-cruise-missile-failed-weapon-test.html) and the "final" Zircon test (https://ria.ru/20210512/rakety-1732016988.html).
August is getting closer...gonna downgrade just a bit, but I think there's still a good chance.

https://www.autoevolution.com/news/russias-fierce-sarmat-missile-closer-to-deployment-with-three-tests-this-year-160966.html
First test likely Q3. Since the time frame of the question covers one third of Q3, maybe 33%, but I think the end of Q3 is more likely than the beginning.
I'm at about 20% but compensating for an earlier higher forecast.

The first test has been announced by the Russians to take place in the 3rd quarter of 2021 (July, August and September). Only a third of this period is in the question window, so I think it's fair to give this a one-third chance.  Source: https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9545125/Russia-announces-tests-Putins-invincible-hypersonic-Satan-2-super-nuke.html

I'm going to tenatively say that Russia is full of baloney. "The first launch of the Sarmat ICBM within the framework of flight development tests will be carried out tentatively in the third quarter of 2021, a field at the Kura testing range on Kamchatka will be a target," another source said. https://tass.com/defense/1286447

Comments: A lot of hardware on display during the dress rehearsal, both tactical and strategic (RS-24 Yars). A successful Sarmat launch would be a nice touch, in contrast to the aborted Minuteman III launch a couple of days ago. Affirming forecast.
Daily Mail, 05/07/21, 'Putin’s glamorous troops prepare alongside Russia’s deadliest weaponry in Moscow’s Red Square as they rehearse for Sunday’s WW2 Victory Day parade': https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9554265/Putins-glamorous-troops-rehearse-Sundays-WW2-Victory-Day-parade.html
Air Force Times, 05/05/21, 'Air Force aborts test launch of unarmed Minuteman III nuclear missile': https://www.airforcetimes.com/news/your-air-force/2021/05/05/air-force-aborts-test-launch-of-unarmed-minuteman-iii-nuclear-missile/

Comments: Good comments by @Zauchka and @Greyowlsova. On track to start lowering my probability after May 9. Affirming forecast.
TASS, 05/04/21, 'Russia to hold three test launches of its newest Sarmat ICBM this year — source': https://tass.com/defense/1286447

Russian sources report the first of the three flight tests planned for 2021 is expected in Q3. Meaning, it could be after the 1 August resolution date for this question. Chances of delays and unreliability of Russian news sources are also sth to consider. https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11307631

So, here we go again. "Sources" in Russian military-industrial complex told TASS that it will be 3 launches in 2021 and one of them will be in the 3rd quarter. All of them will be launched from Plesetsk (near Arkhangelsk, Northwest of Russia) to Kura (on Kamchatka, far Northeast.) LONG flight. https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11307631 (in Russian). Wasn't the same planned in 2019? But of course, the more time passes, the more probability is that it would happen.  Putin said at first the 1st regiment would be equipped by Sarmats in 2021, then this moved to 2022. Still, his word is on the line. 3rd quarter is July-September, which includes August 1 - just one month before, two after. Even with evenly distributed probability, just 33%, But, with delays, Putin's announcements, the stakes are high and the 1st launch should be deemed successful. So, if it happens, I think it is not an even distribution, but rather skewed toward August or even September. Still I'll be upping my forecast ever so slightly. Regardless, current 75% consensus seems high to me.
Moving up a little in confidence in "capability" with well identified post from @Zauchka (with thanks!). https://thebulletin.org/premium/2021-03/nuclear-notebook-russian-nuclear-weapons-2021/

Moving up. This project has been plagued by delays, but it appears the testing ground has been completed (see below). Still planned for this summer, following successful recent tests elsewhere of the modernized arsenal (eg in Kazakhstan; a torpedo in the Arctic) and a failed cruise missile launch near Vladivostok. Overall, lots of activity. Not sure if it means Sarmat is more or less likely. 
https://thebulletin.org/premium/2021-03/nuclear-notebook-russian-nuclear-weapons-2021/
“Russia is also developing the heavy SS-29, or Sarmat (RS-28), which will begin replacing the SS-18 (RS-20V) at Uzhur in 2021 or 2022. Three ejection tests were conducted in December 2017, March 2018, and May 2018 at the Plesetsk Space Center, involving cold launch and test firing of the Sarmat’s first stage and booster engine. These tests were originally scheduled for 2016 but were delayed because of difficulties that appeared during the missile’s strength tests. The closing test stages, which will include a test launch with the 62nd Missile Division at Uzhur, was supposed to be completed by the end of 2020; however, this has been delayed, likely due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. In December 2020, Defense Minister Shoigu suggested that Sarmat flight tests would take place during the summer of 2021 at the new Severo-Yeniseysky proving ground (Russian Federation 2020a). Following the success of these tests, Sarmat will officially be handed over to the military and serial production will begin. As of March 2020, Sarmat’s industrial production line has apparently completed all the necessary upgrades to prepare for serial production, which is expected to begin in 2021, barring any unforeseen delays (TASS 2020c; Safronov and Nikolsky 2019).“

If you believe Putin, Sarmat should be fully deployed by “the end of 2022”. Start of flight tests (5 in total) still planned for 2021. But 1 August is a lot nearer now and the statements are still nebulous. 
https://anna-news.info/raketnyj-kompleks-sarmat-zastupit-na-boevoe-dezhurstvo-v-2022-godu/

Many of Russia's claims have proven to be propaganda/hype.  With any weapons platform development, there are/will be, delays.  The potential for a flight test in November 2021 is far better than before August 1st 2021.

Actually l intended to decrease my forecast more drastically. As Putin has been talking about Sarmat deployment for a few years now, the propaganda loss of unsuccessful launch increased, l surmise. So the 1st launch should be successful, which means later flight tests.
The deployment of Sarmats was moved to the end of 2022, clear sign they are having troubles.

While the sample size is low, it seems Russia likes to test rockets not earlier than mid August and no later than January or February, essentially favoring the winter months. This would be somewhat consistent with the public goal of being in service in 2022.

Let's say it takes a reasonable 6 months to complete the first flight test after finishing the facilities (the latter of which reportedly happened within the last few weeks). Let's assume 6 months is the average time it takes and assign it 50% probability in 6 months. 3.8 months left divided by 6 months average is 63%. That's approx 63% to average, or 32%. Cut this in half because it seems they would need to test the rocket engines first before trying to launch a test flight; it appears they have not tested the second and third stage engines publicly. Misc.: They tested ejection systems in 2018. It takes SpaceX 1 to 2 years to assemble one of their rockets. . . . https://thediplomat.com/2020/03/russia-upgrades-facility-to-produce-rs-28-sarmat-icbm/ Update: Flight tests are desired for the second and third stage engines. Oops.

Talked myself into a raise! https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1234493 Weather will have a significant impact on the optimal timing for a rocket flight test - particularly temperature, sky electricity, air pressure and turbulence / wind speed in and around the testing site [1 & 2].  As such, and when looking at met conditions around Plesetsk Cosmodrome [3 & 4], a first flight test window between April & June 21 would be in bounds for this question. [1] https://www.fi.edu/blog/How-Does-Weather-Affect-a-Rocket-Launch%3F#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20a%20light%20wind,push%20the%20rocket%20off%2Dcourse.
[2] http://russianforces.org/blog/2017/12/sarmat_ejection_test_at_last.shtml
[3] https://www.globalsecurity.org/space/world/russia/plesetsk.htm
[4] https://weatherspark.com/y/101904/Average-Weather-in-Plesetsk-Russia-Year-Round

Comments: 'Does not change the fact that they consider each other an enemy' 
USA has appeared to have recently tested/deployed all three components of it's [nuclear] Triad. RU, two (air and sea). Affirming forecast.
The Daily Sabah, 02/14/21, 'Expectations from START treaty as US, Russia recommit': https://www.dailysabah.com/world/expectations-from-start-treaty-as-us-russia-recommit/news
Clips from Sabah article:
'Without hindering the creation of new missile systems, the treaty limits the number of nuclear weapons in use and obliges each side to show each other new weapons before putting them into service, providing necessary transparency, Litovkin said.'
'"Nevertheless, both the Pentagon and the Russian General Staff wanted to extend this agreement, but for different reasons. The U.S. cares about maintaining the verification regime – mutual on-site inspections of nuclear carriers, exchange of telemetry of test missiles launches and other sensitive information. Our General Staff is interested in extending New START because, without it, the Americans can deploy additional nuclear carriers in a short time," he said.
Although both sides want transparency, that does not change the fact that they consider each other an enemy. "Not that they are going to fight – they are not, but they are ready to balance on the brink of war," Felgengauer said.
Another problem is that the treaty is signed only for five years and does not provide for a further extension. "And it is not even clear whether it will last all these five years, because any of the parties can denounce it at any time, and the parties have lots of mutual claims.
"In particular, the U.S. insists on involving China, but there are other nuclear-armed countries. Then you need to bring them to negotiations as well. But given the difficulties that existed with the extension of the New START, signed between only two countries, the preparation and signing of another arms control agreement in just five years and between many countries seems almost unrealistic," Felgengauer said.

Although the system has reportedly been delayed in coming online, Putin himself is now saying it is entering its final stages of development, and the deputy minister of defense is saying that testing is imminent. While the wording allows for some significant squishiness in terms of specific timing, nobody wants the big bosses to look bad. I estimate that they'll be doing everything in their power to get at least one test done as soon as possible. That said, if the test were a failure, it'd be a disaster on the international stage, so look for the Russians to do everything possible to make sure the first one is a success, even if it means delaying longer. My forecast is pretty rough right now. I'd really like to see more information regarding actual work to begin the testing phase.

Plenty of political motivations to carry out a test of this new capability (especially as a distraction from the current internal struggles and as a show of strength in the face of a newly authoritative US) and very few geo-political reasons to not test it [1]. [1]  https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesrodgerseurope/2020/12/19/russia-in-2021-six-things-to-watch/ Russian diplomats reportedly suggested that Sarmat and Avangard "could" be included under the extended treaty [2], but with Avangard having already been deployed (in December 2019) during the original START treaty's effective period it doesn't seem that START is an effective barrier to the testing, trials and deployment of new capabilities (or "replacements" from Russia's interpretation).   Given how much money Russia has already ploughed into Sarmat's development it seems very unlikely the extended (and largely unenforced) START treaty is going to stop them from completing the development programme. [2] https://www.nbc12.com/2021/01/22/russian-welcomes-us-proposal-extend-nuclear-treaty/ The only obviously pressing reason to not carry out such a test would be for fear of technical failure that could turn a show of strength into a public humiliation.  With testing and assurance having been going on as long as they have [3], and with the declared in service date of 2022 looming it seems likely that a flight test will have been technically de-risked to the point where it's given the go. [3] https://tass.com/defense/1241159

So... Be advised - I do not have any expertise in ICBMs, how they are developed, tested etc. And haven't really researched. But even at a glance, the crowd consensus may be too high. 1. Sarmat was supposed to be tested in 2020. Never happened.
2. If I understand correctly, they only are STARTING to build a missile range to test it. Of course, I do not know what it means - I assume. not much, besides fencing and some infrastructure - roads, targets(?), recording devices... Still...
3. They are going to employ them in 2022 on limited scale (in two militarily units) , but on mass scale, it looks like, only by the end of the decade.
4. Americans have been having problems with equivalent ICBMs - the forecasted speed was twice the recorded. And the recorded was like.. what, 6 times slower than Sarmat? Are Russians are THAT better? They 9and Americans) may be just against some laws of physics to make them reliably.
5. Russian military budget went through the cycle of financing of new weapons and modernization of forces. Now it may be actually shrinking.
6. Do Russians need to accelerate this program since START is being agreed upon? Recent posturing with Sarmat (most activity last December) may well be just prodding to attract attention of the Biden administration and sign START. Some amateurish thoughts. Nothing more... Sorry, I don't provide references.

Putin and defense officials are claiming the RS-28 Sarmat is in the final stages of production and will be ready for tests soon. Russia will likely continue to delay tests until it is certain that the RS-28 Sarmat will succeed due to the reputational damage that would be inflicted by a failed test. Overall, more concrete dates or evidence are needed before I increase my forecast.

The article WAS recently posted on this less-than-reliable website, so it may not reflect true conversations that took place during the Trump administration.  However, there was a 25 Mar 2020 article on Tass which also postures; “Russia completes upgrade of facilities for serial production of Sarmat ICBMs” (from previous spring) https://tass.com/defense/1135095 29 Dec 2020 Article: “Flight trials of Russia’s Sarmat ICBM to begin soon — deputy minister,” states that they plan to soon set up a testing range in Siberia. So it seems I made a small arithmetic error on my previous forecast. 2/3 = 66%, not 60%

Navalny arrived from Germany somewhat like Lenin at Finland Station in April 1917. 4 months later the Bolsheviks with perhaps less than 1 percent support routed Kerensky and the democratically elected Duma at the Winter Palace in less than 5 Percent. Will Putin run for another term, Peskov says no in the meantime expect more Sputnik events from vaccine to defense for national prestige.

a. Initial Assessment Russian ICBM tests: The Russians have conducted three silo ejection tests of the Sarmat, one in 2017 and two in 2018 (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/30/russia-tests-its-new-nuclear-intercontinental-ballistic-missile.html, https://missilethreat.csis.org/russia-to-deploy-sarmat-icbm-in-2021/). So the missile is ready for flight tests. Since it’s going into service in 2022 (https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9110579/Russia-planning-flight-test-new-missile-capable-destroying-area-size-France.html ), testing will likely be started, if not completed, this year. 2 out of 3 of the silo ejection tests were conducted from January-August 2018, so I’m going with a 60% base probability. Add 15% to this for the pressure from tests of new US hypersonic missiles and ballistic missile interceptors (https://www.defense.gov/Explore/News/Article/Article/2225296/hypersonics-testing-accelerates/, https://abcnews.go.com/US/us-successfully-intercepts-icbm-ship-launched-missile-historic/story?id=74248760 ), and 75% is what I’m starting with.
To maintain status equilibrium in an upward trajectory within the world stage.

Now seems like a good time to do so, especially if intended for wide adoption by 2022. As long as Putin keeps remembering to pay the light and cable bills. https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9110579/Russia-planning-flight-test-new-missile-capable-destroying-area-size-France.html

Although the testing of the Sarmat missile has faced a number of delays, the missile ejection tests have been successfully completed and it appears that flight tests of the missile are now imminent.  Russia's Strategic Missile Forces commander Sergey Karakayev said in December the Sarmat will enter combat duty by 2022.

Initial forecast, just slightly above consensus. There is whether it is needed or wanted, perhaps for non-technical reasons. In the latter category, I might expect less than normal RDT&E. The whole notion of another nuclear arms race is something the presumed nuclear powers might wish to de-emphasize. Since Russia has a significantly diverse capability, worrying about one system is less important than in the past. Testing means signatures which have to be weighed against benefits.

Putin needs to get back into the news.  https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9110579/Russia-planning-flight-test-new-missile-capable-destroying-area-size-France.html They've stated deployment in 2021, probably good to get a few tests in before that:
